head.title: Police Say Videotape May Lead to Killers of a Man in Queens

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York

hedline.hl1: Police Say Videotape May Lead to Killers of a Man in Queens

abstract.p: NYC police release videotape that they hope will lead to people who killed Jong-Rin Lee with cobblestone after following him into lobby of his Queens apartment building (M)

block.p: The police released a videotape yesterday that they hope will lead to the people who killed a father of four with a cobblestone after following him into the lobby of his Queens apartment building.
The man, Jong-Rin Lee, 46, died last Tuesday at New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens after suffering injuries that included fractures to his skull and ribs, the authorities said.
The police released a videotape yesterday that they hope will lead to the people who killed a father of four with a cobblestone after following him into the lobby of his Queens apartment building.
The man, Jong-Rin Lee, 46, died last Tuesday at New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens after suffering injuries that included fractures to his skull and ribs, the authorities said.

The assault took place about 1:15 a.m. on Sept. 23, as Mr. Lee was returning to his home on 147th Street from his job at a Korean restaurant in Manhattan, the police said. Their investigation into the incident was first reported in The Daily News.

The attack itself was not captured by the security camera in the lobby. But the black-and-white videotape from the camera does show the two assailants entering the lobby of Mr. Lee's building, then bolting less than a minute later, the police said. About 10 seconds after the first suspect is seen entering the building, his head covered with a bandanna, a second suspect wearing a dark bandanna with white polka dots enters, carrying a cobblestone that appears so heavy it must be held with two hands.
The police described the assailants as Hispanic, each about 17 years old and between 5 feet 6 inches and 5 feet 8 inches tall.
The police said one suspect was a male, but they were not certain of the other one's gender.
''Based on the original description, we're going with male. If it turns out to be a female, I would not be surprised,'' said Inspector Joseph Reznick, the commander of detectives in Queens.
The police are investigating the case as a possible bias crime. They are also looking into the possibility that the killing was part of a gang initiation or a botched robbery.
''Right now we have nothing to indicate to us that it is bias,'' Inspector Reznick said. ''However, we are looking at everything.''
The police said nothing appeared to be missing from Mr. Lee's pockets, which contained his keys and wallet, a MetroCard and $1.50.
One avenue the police are pursuing involves the Mara Salvatrucha, or MS-13, a gang formed by Salvadorans, whose logo is scrawled on Mr. Lee's building, the police said.
''These tags are very conspicuously written up on the walls of that particular building,'' Inspector Reznick said, calling the gang's activities ''one of many motives that we're looking at.''
